title: December 26
description:
Joyeux Noël from Paris!

This is the first year we know for sure that Felix doesn't believe in Santa. He was on a Skype video chat with a friend in Berkeley and we overheard them discussing the matter. Friend whispers, "Do you think Santa is your parents?" Felix whispers back, "Y - E - S".

We've suspected Felix hasn't actually believed in Santa since he was four; we don't think he's ever going to bring it up himself. Given that Milo still believes, Felix is being very considerate and not bursting Milo's Santa bubble.

Milo is starting to have his doubts, though, as evidenced by this very philosophical bedtime conversation:
" - Mommy, does Santa really exist?
- What do you think?
- I just don't know. I have to find out for sure before I am a grown-up. What if I still believe in Santa when I am grown-up? I won't buy presents for my kids then. And if Santa doesn't exist, then my kids won't get any presents.
- That wouldn't be good.
- Kids can believe in Santa, but grown-ups have to know for sure."

We are impressed with Milo's very clear distinguishing between belief and knowledge.

And this is also surely the last Christmas that we'll be able to write stuff in the website without both Felix and Milo reading it.

This was the first time in years that Nana didn't make it for Christmas, and she was missed. She was planning to come but there's been massive snow problems at the French airports so she canceled her ticket. Instead, she's on a cruise in the Caribbean, hitting 7 countries in 7 days. Remember your sunscreen, Nana!

children.title: Noël 2010
children.description:
Christmas is coming!

Do you hear that sound? It's the cre-e-eaking of kids' excitement stretching dangerously near the breaking point as gifts accumulate under the tree day by day, marching unbearably slowly towards Christmas day.

children.title: Window Licking
children.description: Americans call it window shopping. The French, always ready with an elegant turn of phrase, call it "lèche-vitrine": window licking.

children.title: Christmas Pastimes
children.description: After the snowy adventure of the first few days of the winter vacation, we settled into more sedate holiday pursuits: cards, cooking, and growing our waistlines.

children.title: Couchful of Readers
children.description:
Snow on the ground and snug on the couch.

Our first white Christmas!

children.title: Guest of Honor
children.description: Look who's the guest of honor on Christmas Eve!

children.title: Christmas Eve Supper
children.description:
Françoise, Pol and the nuclear family settle down for a long winter's feast.

The lobster and mussels were followed up with a light-as-a-cloud île flottante, Felix's favorite dessert.

children.title: Night Before Xmas
children.description: 'Twas the night before Christmas, when all through the house, not a creature was stirring, except for the munch-munch-munch of a little mouse on the cookies.

children.title: Claus' Cookies
children.description:
"PUR Peti PAPA NÖEL" = "Pour Petit Papa Nöel" = "For Santa"

Milo made absolutely sure Santa knew the cookies and carrot were for his team.

children.title: No One On The Naughty List
children.description:
In what has become a Christmas tradition we hope WON'T last, the night went just about like 2009:
  • 3am: Milo comes to our bed, asking if it's morning. He stays in our bed, trembling with excitement.
  • 3:15: Milo asks, "is it morning?". We have a serious-as-death conversation about waiting for the numbers "7:00" to show on the alarm clock.
  • 4:00: Milo goes to check on the tree. Santa's arrived!! Squeals of excitement. Pitter patter up to Felix's room. Excited whispers and stompling on the stairs wake up the grandparents as well.
  • 4:30: Milo back in our bed, vibrating.
  • 6:15: Felix flings open our door and turns on the light. Has his head bitten off by two extremely grumpy adults jealously guarding the last few minutes of semi-sleep. Backs out VERY quickly.
  • 6:45: Milo, watching every minute tick over on the clock, complains "Lord Chronos is in the room, slowing down time."
  • As soon as the blinking digits read 7:00, two hyperactive nuclear balls of excitement explode on our bed. Huzzah huzzah, another sleep-deprived Christmas morning!

children.title: The Grand Opening
children.description:
As the adults stagger around the kitchen rooting out caffeinated substances, the boys commence the Grand Opening.

Merry Christmas!

children.title: Xmas Lunch With Michele
children.description: Lucie's aunt (Françoise's sister) Michèle and cousin Julien came for a delicious Christmas lunch.

children.title: The Forces Amass
children.description:
We brought virtually no legos to France. Legos require a critical mass of blocks before they become fun to play with. Since August, Felix has very, very patiently waited for his birthday and Christmas to rectify this sorry state of affairs.

Now armed with an entire galaxy of Star Wars legos, General Felix begins planning a massive offensive.

children.title: Battle Royale
children.description: Let the battle begin!

children.title: Crêpes Champs Élysées
children.description: Boxing Evening on the beautiful-but-crowded Champs Élysées.

children.title: Élysées Át Níght
children.description: Oh la la, Champs Élysées, you dress up très belle at Noël!

children.title: Ice Magic
children.description: Would you believe some fool lugged 450 tons of glacier all the way from Vancouver to the Champs Élysées and had 20 sculptors from around the world chainsaw it into works of art?

children.title: Frosty Wave
children.description: The man at the front had a stern talk with everyone (looking at Milo) about what would happen to your tongue if it came into contact with an ice sculpture.

children.title: Crossing the Ice Bridge
children.description: The Moses men mount an ice bridge.

children.title: Manneken Pis
children.description:
Dean steers well clear of the front of Manneken Pis, in case it's sponsored by Absolut Vodka.

Don't know Mannekin Pis? He's a famous statue in Brussels. Legend has it that in the 14th century, Brussels was under siege and the attackers were placing explosives at the city walls. A little boy happened to be spying on them. He urinated on the burning fuse and thus saved the city.

children.title: Not N'ice
children.description: They say it's Mont St. Michel.  We think it's N'ice.

children.title: Vin Chaud
children.description: At a nippy -6°C, Pol hands out vin chaud (hot wine) to bolster our warm holiday spirit.

children.title: Chilly Reception
children.description: Terra cotta ice soldiers guard the booze.

children.title: Pol & Lucie At The Louvre
children.description: Our way home took us past the Louvre.  It was absolutely louvre-ly.

children.title: Eiffel Xmas Suit
children.description: Even the Eiffel Tower puts on a new dress for Christmas!
